nodes.title: Article 4
nodes.summary: This partial document outlines the implementation procedures for a mining cadastre office following a new ministerial order. The main points are that the office must begin compiling specific lists and converting/updating existing, previously confirmed mining titles to bring them into compliance. It also states that this work must be carried out in accordance with relevant legal and regulatory provisions, citing specific articles from the Mining Code and Mining Regulations.

nodes.title: Article 5
nodes.summary: This partial document outlines procedural requirements within a mining and quarry regulations framework. It specifies that individuals claiming or confirming their mining or quarry rights must submit specific forms to the relevant ministry and registry, accompanied by proof and a fee. It establishes deadlines for these submissions, with failure to respond resulting in automatic forfeiture of rights. The text also details procedures for handling disputed claims, including referral to a validation commission and a moratorium on new applications in contested areas while allowing new applications in uncontested areas.

nodes.title: Article 9
nodes.summary:
This partial document contains Articles 9, 10, and 11 of a legal decree (Arrêté). The main points are:

1.  **Article 9:** It mandates holders of validated mining and quarry rights to contact the Mining Cadastre within 90 days (from a specific publication or resolution date) to transform or regularize their rights according to specified regulations.

2.  **Article 10:** It requires applicants with pending applications for mining/quarry rights, renewals, or transformations (filed before the new Mining Code) to reformulate their applications within 90 days of the decree's effective date to maintain their original priority date. Failure to do so results in loss of priority for new applications and automatic nullification for renewal/transformation requests.

3.  **Article 11:** It designates the Secretary General of Mines and the Director General of the Mining Cadastre as responsible for implementing the decree, which entered into force on the date of its signature (July 12, 2005, in Kinshasa).
